The Envision app is definately by far the best app for the blind and visually impaired on the market today. It far surpasses all of the other apps for android due to the fact that it is so easy to use, and gives you auditory guidance when lining up the text for reading and so on. As a user of the app myself, I have come to realize just how useful it can really be in so many situations. At the time of this writing, I am on the free trial version of the app, but I can definitely tell you that this app will bring a level of independence that no other app on the market can bring you. For one thing, the accuracy of the scanning of the text is far superior than any other app. The folks at Envision have really thought of everything! Being blind or visually impaired doesn't have to be a prison any longer. Technology has come to the rescue with Envision, a brand new innovation in wearable and handheld technology that uses artificial intelligence to help the blind and visually impaired to navigate in a sighted world. Now for the first time in history, artificial intelligence is able to help the blind and visually impaired get more information from a sighted world by implementing the reading of text based information in real time, or by taking photos and relaying the information through optical character recognition technology that is second to none in the industry. Not only this, but Envision technology can do so much more. You can use it to describe your surroundings, tell you what color something is, identify faces and even read bar codes and identify certain objects. This means that Envision AI technology can actually learn thus making it the one and only technology for the blind and visually impaired that is fully customizable for each person's individual needs. You see, more and more companies are jumping onto the bandwagon by creating their own wearables and such that are designed to improve the lives of those who are sight impaired. However, Envision is the only company that takes it all a step further and really goes out of the way to research and implement new innovative technologies that other companies can only dream about adding to their products. This is because the people behind Envision are serious about their work, and they want to provide a product that not only works, but actually enriches the lives of the blind and visually impaired all around the world. So whether you have the app installed onto your phone, or you're using the new Envision glasses, you're sure to get as much information as possible about your surroundings and other things that you need on a daily basis that will help you work,learn or play. Envision's optical character recognition is far superior than many other apps and devices on the market today. You can read books, magazines and any text on any surface, even from television screens, computer screens and other digital displays. Envision is the only technology that encorporates real-time reading of text so that if you need to read house numbers, signs or anything else immediately, Envision AI can definitely handle it for you with no problem whatsoever. No other device or app can do this. So whether you're in school, working on the job, or whatever, Envision AI can do what you need it to do throughout your entire day without getting tired or giving up on you. You are able to read any printed text, and even some hand written text as well. The goal of Envision is to make blind or visually impaired people as independent as humanly possible without needing any assistance from a real human, but even if that's needed, you can still get human guidance because you can call someone and they're connected directly into the app, or into the glasses and they're seeing exactly what you see, so they can guid you around objects and such. Here again, no other device on the market can even do this. Envision AI is the only product that can provide this to the user. So as you can see, Envision AI is definitely hands down the winner here. It does far more than any other vision system on the market today.

This seems clever, but it's not. The barcode contains no information - it's just a reference to a database. Companies pay to have their information in there. There are plenty of free barcode standards that can encode information in the code itself. There have been numerous attempts to monetise 2D barcodes and this is yet another. QR codes are free and can hold up to 4K of info with no need for a monetised database or online access. This will be dead within a few years.

I am sighted, and was testing this app for recommendation to my 
non-technical blind friend for daily use. Books and newspapers can be 
accessed and read online these days, and she's looking for a tool to help 
with daily tasks such as counting calories, reading signs, and reading 
product instructions and recipe cards. Unfortunately, I cannot recommend 
this app. I tested it on nutrional facts, and they were spoken without any 
pauses at all, making a list of useful data into a confusing stream of 
alternating numbers and words - it skipped one chart almost entirely! I'm 
not sure if the app even read the calorie information, come to think of it. 
I also tested it using a clear picture of the flat back of a cleaning 
spray, and the cautions and instructions were unintelligible, with quite a 
few strings of rarely-used characters such as carets and mathematical 
symbols inserted into the text. I compared the same image of the back of 
the chemical spray using Google translate OCR, and it handled adequately, 
conveying the meaning of the instructions clearly enough to be useful - so 
the legibility of the recognized text is definitely not due to the quality 
of the image. I suspect aerosols would fare more poorly! I do like the 
option to tell you the orientation of the page, but even that could be 
improved by perhaps using a series of bells (low for counterclockwise, high 
for clockwise, and tinkling when centered, for instance) to direct 
orientation instead of relying on a guess-and-check system.

I have no problem recommending this app and the other thing i'll say is working with microsoft's seeingAI staff via email you get quick responces. I do not work with them but what I mean is like emailing them, their turnaround time has ben rather snappy I feel. they seem to really get blind people with their seeingAI here and its just getting better.edit, as of Version 5.5, the interface is much more streamlined, I didn't think it possible to make it any easier but they did, and they blended a few channels into one, like the read tab is short text and document all in one and you also have the option to toggle with a button with document alignment and you can even take a photo in that tab. theres so much more they did and its just excellent and we still get access to the older stuff. I just downloaded this app, and so far, I‚Äôm really impressed with its functionality. Please keep it going! I‚Äôm not blind, nor is my dad, who I actually downloaded it for. He was diagnosed with Lewy Body dementia, which causes hallucinations, making it difficult for him to distinguish between what‚Äôs real and what‚Äôs not. He once mentioned that he wished he could point his phone at something and have it tell him whether it was real. That led me to search for apps, and I came across this one.

We plan to use it during his episodes‚Äîeither he can use his phone himself, or we, as caregivers, can assist him‚Äîso he can have confirmation of reality. I‚Äôm especially impressed with the describe feature and how detailed it is in explaining what‚Äôs being seen. So far, I‚Äôm really happy with it. Keep up the great work!

Overall, I have found this app very useful and accomplishing day-to-day tasks such as identifying canned goods or sorting the mail. However, it is very inconsistent ( and unacceptably so) in its ability to read the output of digital displays. FYI, I am speaking throughout this review of the short text channel. I use this app every day to read my kitchen scale for making coffee and for other reasons. At times, it reads the output quickly and accurately. At other times, it takes a very, very, very, very, very long time to read the display. Words are inadequate to describe the frustration I feel when a 30-second task turns into a 10-minute one, draining my phone battery all the while. If a pair of human eyeballs can read the display, then there should be no reason why Seeing AI cannot also read it. This problem seems particularly exacerbated by readings that end in either 1 or 7 (such as 21 G). The app has no problem reading the labels of the buttons on the scale, but it all too often fails to read literally the only thing on the display I want to hear. Perhaps a new channel could be created in the app that is optimized specifically for the reading of displays. Please work on this! In a world in which many home appliances are still inaccessible, it is more important than ever that blind people have access to an app like Seeing AI that is capable of reading a display. My rating reflects the frustration caused by the app's seeming inability to accomplish one of its core functions in situations that I need it most. I commit to updating my rating when this issue is addressed.

Before now, all problems that I had run into seemed to be fixed, but now, I ran into an issue with a wrong product. I was looking for my members Mark onion powder, and instead of telling me that it was onion powder, it told me that it was GV thin spaghetti. I obviously knew that was not thin spaghetti, and decided to start opening packages to see what they were so that I could find the right thing. It turned out that what it told me was spaghetti, was the onion powder that I was looking for. it's fortunate for everybody in my household that I'm not the one with the cold that I was making soup for, or we could've ended up with something really off the wall in the soup because I wouldn't have been able to smell it. The problem is, when we run into a problem like this, there's no button to report a problem, so it's going to start telling everybody that members mark onion powder is great value thin spaghetti, which if you shake it, it's obviously not, and it's not even in a container that thin spaghetti would be in, but for somebody who has never cooked, or is just learning, they won't know that it's the wrong kind of package. Spaghetti is typically in cellophane or cardboard, and this giant thing of onion powder is a plastic container. This is something that we need. We need to be able to report a wrong product if it's telling us that it's one thing, when it isn't. I have known older people who store everything in the same place, whether it's edible or not, if it's kitchen related, it goes in the cupboard, regardless. I have known people who have stored rat poison in the same cupboard as spices because it's too high for kids to get into, and I would really hate for somebody to put rat poison in their food by accident because this app told them that it was something edible. I'm not one of these people, and don't even keep rat poison in my house, but unfortunately, I know people who do. I could see this being a deadly mistake if we don't have a place to report wrong product uPC's. also, in one developer response to somebody, it says go to seeingai.com to see improvements in the app, but that just takes us right back here to the App Store.

‚Ä¢ People Recognition has to be done by taking their picture & many refuse to allow that. It would be easier if it can be done by a previously taken photo. This way permission isn‚Äôt needed to know who is around you!
‚Ä¢ Vague description on objects & animals. Would love to know if it‚Äôs my dachshund or Chihuahua eating or just came in, I already know both are dogs!
Tips -

‚Ä¢ Adding the option to use previous taken photos to recognize those around us.

I installed this app the day I first heard of it, while listening to the ACB national convention nearly two years ago.  Even though I had had KNFB Reader for a number of years, I mainly added this one for comparison, but soon discovered that it compares favorably with the aforementioned app, as well as with other light-detecting, color-identifying and currency-reading apps I have used over the last five years. I soon realized that I needed to get a newer iPhone in order to use the Products feature‚Äîwhich I did.  I use the app just about every day, for everything from reading mail to reading books, some magazines, and cooking instructions on that packaged dinner I just pulled out of the freezer, and even making sure that coupon I plan to use at a local business hasn‚Äôt expired.  The Short Text works especially well, for those times you don‚Äôt wish to scan an entire document.  For most things, the Document channel works well, and I like it that the focusing is done automatically.  However, there are occasions when I get the ‚ÄúNo text recognized‚Äù alert; so then, I revert to KNFB Reader, and sometimes it does a better job reading that document.  I am totally blind from birth; so I am assuming that the documents for which I get that alert are those printed in multiple colors, and with numerous graphics that land smack in the middle of the written text.  I can‚Äôt vouch for the color identifier channel‚Äîas I have never been able to see color; but, knowing that lighting can affect the way color is perceived‚Äîeven by a good set of eyes‚Äîmy take is that any attempt at a color identifier is better than none at all.  The currency reader has improved markedly since the app first came out.  I have been able to read a number of handwritten greeting cards‚Äîand other items as well‚Äîwith the Handwriting channel.  The light detector has saved me any amount of grief, since I have a number of light switches (for overhead lights, of course), which are push-buttons rather than up-and-down toggles; and, we all know people who can‚Äôt remember to turn the lights off when they leave.  I‚Äôve had considerable fun with the Scene channel, which is often quite accurate.  I have occasionally had a bit of difficulty getting the bar-code reader (Product channel) to work; but then, bar codes aren‚Äôt always in the same location on a box or container.  Just today, I had to search diligently for the bar code on a frozen meal, in order to then read the cooking instructions.  By the time I found and read that information, my battery status had dropped precipitously, from 85 to 60 percent!  If one is using the app for any length of time at a stretch, I suggest that they either have their phone plugged in, or have an external battery handy, as it is a major drain.  On the other hand, this afternoon I was able to read an online menu‚Äîwhich was otherwise totally inaccessible because it was an _image‚Äî from a local restaurant.  In this case, SeeingAI did a better job reading it than KNFB Reader!  Finally, to those who insist that there is no currency reader channel, could it be that they are still on an iPhone 5S or earlier?  And to those who insist that the app doesn‚Äôt work well with VoiceOver, perhaps they are just new to VoiceOver and need help with it?  This has really been a life-changing app!  I look forward to even more improvements and enhancements, and apologize for the length of this review.

I would recommend this app to anyone who is completely blind, or low vision like me. The best parts of this app for me are it‚Äôs ability to read short text on the fly, or capture entire documents in just a few seconds. This app rivals paid apps like DigitEyes and KNFBReader. I can‚Äôt speak for KNFBReader as I don‚Äôt own that app, but SeeingAI, in my experience, detects products just as good or even better than DigitEyes, as for it‚Äôs recognition of text on paper or a computer screen, I‚Äôve not had any complaints about it. Things that need improvement are the money reader, scene recognition, and color recognition. Those features are relatively new, so I expect them to improve with updates. The app gets a five star recommendation from me, for anyone with even a slight visual impairment.

Very good at doing so many things and a fun way to play around with image detection AI!  Barcode reader is the best one I've ever used. Face detection seems extremely well implemented, I was able to quickly take a nicely framed up selfie using the back camera and the audio cues from the app. It tells you the subject's gender, age, and mood.  And then there's the scene detection where you take a picture and it does its best to describe what it sees. It's not always accurate but it's usually pretty close, and sometimes it can come up with some interesting feedback. 

Everything feels VERY snappy, at least on my iPhone 7 Plus on my home WiFi. The voice is so responsive and quick that using the app feels almost futuristic at times. This is the main thing that differentiates this from things I've seen before. It feels a bit like an Apple product‚Äî none of these AI technologies is new, but it's the first time they are all together in one accessible place and so well executed. 

The only thing that didn't work for me was the document detection feature, I tried many times to scan a receipt on A4 paper from an online purchase and it appeared to recognize the geometry of the paper very well and quickly asked me to hold still but then said there wasn't any text found while displaying a black screen where there would normally be an image. Apparently a minor bug which I hope they'll hammer out in the next release.

Very infrequently does an app come along which can have a real impact on improving the day-to-day lives of visually impaired people, many have tried and often don‚Äôt succeed.

Since it‚Äôs first launch in the UK Seeing AI has become a permanent fixture on my home screen for the main reason that it is helpful. As a visually impaired person, simple tasks such as reading product labels atop shelves In a large store can become both a complicated and embarrassing experience; however, with Seeing AI‚Äôs short text channel it becomes much easier to independently find what I‚Äôm looking for. Meanwhile, the document channel can be very useful if there is a printed page to read, I have found a relative consistency in the accuracy of the scanning and for standard printed documents it has proved to be very accurate on many occasions. Version 2 has also brought a number of enhancements such as multiple currency recognition and colour detection, which could be really useful for some people.

As of right now, Seeing AI isn‚Äôt ‚Äòperfect‚Äô as there are still some enhancements and needed improvements concerning factors especially regarding the ability to read different types of text, such as on a destination display board or picking out information with busy documents such as a restaurant Menu. However, Seeing AI has a great team of committed people behind them and have already made significant usability enhancements such as the use of 3D Touch on newer iPhone models to quickly reach a desired channel quickly.

Overall, for anyone who has a visual impairment Seeing AI is more than just a worthwhile download. It is a genuinely useful mobility aid, which in some cases is able to allow more tasks to be undertaken independently. Whilst there are still some improvements and enhancements which can be made to improve the experience, for the price of nothing there is no reason not to give Seeing AI a chance.
Finally something useful for us

Cannot thank Microsoft enough  for this set of accessibility aids in Seeing AI, now including handwriting recognition.  If you‚Äôre VI and haven‚Äôt downloads this app do it now, it‚Äôs a true life changer!

I won‚Äôt write much here, because for those of you who are interested and who are looking for this app, they will know exactly what it does and what it is, however I just want to say a big thank you to Microsoft for finally releasing this incredibly useful app here in the UK. First, thanks to the developers of envision AI for staying so engaged with the user community and constantly making the app better. It is really a valuable tool! My favorite thing about this app is the document scanner. It is by far the most accurate OCR I‚Äôve ever experienced on my iPhone. A couple years ago I purchased something called KNFB reader which if I recall was like $100 and it cannot compete with envision OCR. The instant text feature can be very useful but I feel it also has room for further development. It continuously re-scans what you are aiming it at, sometimes resulting in garbled output, and it constantly cuts off and interrupts its own output even if you barely move your phone. It‚Äôs really a game of seeing if you can make out what it says well enough to at least accomplish the task. For example, if I aim it at a carton that I pull out of the fridge and I hear something that sounds similar to ‚Äúmilk‚Äù or ‚Äúhalf-and-half,‚Äù I know what I‚Äôve just grabbed, but I really think it could work a lot more smoothly. I have a suggestion ‚Äì somehow combine the object recognition and instant text technologies such that the instant text reader has some awareness of what you are pointing it at. In my milk carton example, it would know that it‚Äôs reading within the bounds of that object which might help it focus. Along similar lines, I have a heck of a time getting it to read LCD screens on home appliances and electronics. I wish there was a way you could tell it to recognize an LCD screen and have it only focus on text that appears on that screen. This is a suggestion I made a while back and it hasn‚Äôt been implemented yet, but I can‚Äôt imagine others wouldn‚Äôt find it helpful. Giving it five stars because overall I still think it‚Äôs outstanding, but I hope to see it continue to improve. Thank you
Always there when I need it to find things I‚Äôve lost or try to read small print very helpful and at my side when I need it.

Supersense is a great all in one tool for accessing many features in one app. My phone screen is scattered with various blindness apps to help me do something or another. An app for reading money, an app for just quickly reading something I found, another app for quickly importing and reading a picture from the share sheet, ETC. this app is nice in the sense that it combines these all together limiting my array of apps I juggle around on a daily bases. 
Probably my favorite and most used feature is how the scanned text is displayed. Instead of your traditional screen where it just reads you the hole page of text, and you have to switch to line navigation or something similar if you want to read individual parts. They break the text into blocks, and it is super fluent to read the exact parts you need. Not only that, but you can copy these blocks of text easily to your clipboard via the roader.
Now, one thing I see people are concerned about is the price. It is subscription based. You can purchase a monthly, yearly, or a lifetime subscription. I don‚Äôt have much else to say on that, other than if you are worried about the price, you can download and try it out for free. Also, if you maybe don‚Äôt have the money to afford the app, at the bottom of the subscription signup page, you will find the following message.
‚ÄúYou may qualify for a reimbursement for your subscription from a state organization. Tap to request assistance and we will reach out to you with additional information.‚Äù
I am not exactly sure who all that would apply to, but it sounds like they are willing to work with you to get you any help you need. I think that is really great of them, and speaks very highly of them as a company.

I‚Äôd had this app for more than three years, and have really liked   it overall, even though I am a bit of a klutz.  However, with Version 3.0, it has become much more difficult to use, at least for this user.  For one thing, the new user manual isn‚Äôt very helpful; it tells us what the app can do, but doesn‚Äôt really tell us _how to do things. With this significant an update, giving us the how-to is extremely important. For instance, importing text from other sources used to be very straightforward‚Äîand it worked well.  Now, when I try to import something, I first have to find where the material _went.  At first, in this version, it went into a folder called ‚ÄúInbox‚Äù (not even mentioned in the user manual).  With the latest update, however, ‚ÄúInbox‚Äù is gone, and I have to search for it among the saved files, even though it technically hasn‚Äôt been saved yet.  Then, I have to go through all kinds of hoops to save the document in a form that will recognize the text.  Sometimes, the field of view report doesn‚Äôt work now.  The whole thing is just harder to use, especially if I am saving documents.  If the user manual were written from the viewpoint of a _new user, it would benefit all of us.  Prior to this, I would have given it a higher rating.
Update, Jan. 10, 2019: It just keeps getting worse. It still does reasonably well for reading and saving otherwise inaccessible material from websites; but, with iOS 12 and later, scanning documents such as books, magazines, and even mail is becoming less successful. Even reinstalling the app didn‚Äôt help. More often than not, the reading comes out Like gibberish now; the automatic picture function almost _never works, and the field of view report is frequently unavailable; at times, it says that the page is upside down when it isn‚Äôt; and, in fact, just about the only people who _might be able to benefit from scanning documents with it are sighted users who have different reading difficulties, such as dyslexia. Really, there should be one app for sightless users, and a different one for sighted users. That way, more focus could be given to having all features working and updated. I‚Äôm only keeping the three stars because of the ability to import text from otherwise inaccessible websites.

This app has gotten much better and much more useful than it has been in the past and I like that. I look forward to seeing how much better this app will become. I don‚Äôt think that the recognition is getting any better in the last few releases. Also this application never completely leaves my system. Even if I go into the app switcher and close it that way, I‚Äôve got to restart my phone to get it to stop vibrating. Also in the most recent releases, it doesn‚Äôt go back to picture mode if there is no text. I personally find the new tab arrangement more difficult to work with than the original one. My old Nokia and 82 with one of the original versions, seems to still work better. I am using an iPhone 7.

1. When I photograph multiple pages and allow them to process, then try to add more images to the existing file, I can only do it one image at a time.
2. The automatic photo feature just does not work, period.
3. Half the time in manual photo mode using the volume buttons fails to work to take the photo, but at random times it does work.
4. If I photograph multiple images and allow them to process, then go straight into listening to them, the reading accuracy is much higher as the app reads directly from the photograph. However, if I close the app or switch files for too long the images convert into PDF-looking files and much of the text becomes gibberish.
5. The incessant refocusing in the camera app is frustrating because I have to try to time when I press the button, or else it takes a blurry photo.
6. Only one voice option.
7. Button symbols are bizarre and difficult to understand, I don't use any other text-to-voice converters so I only have the visual cues.
8. It is difficult to upload a file, I still cannot figure out how.

I've only had this app for four days and have already run into so many issues. Why does this cost $100 if it barely functions? I'm a poor grad student.

Horrible. What happened to this app? For some reason I cannot change the English voice to anything but Fred. I am not impressed with the new user interface either. I can use it however it is not as straightforward as it use to be. it just seems cluttered. I agree with other reviewers  that   saving files and importing them is needlessly  more  complicated. My biggest complaint with this app is the fact that I can only use Fred using English. There is no way I would pay full price for this app now.

I miss the easy way you use to be able to access imported files from another app, it use to be that explorer was at the top of the screen and tapping on this instantly opened your imported file.  Also ever since IOS12 the app will throw you back to the home screen upon launching however it remains active, going to the app switcher and taping on it will put you right back at the home screen.
Other than that it is a very accurate app and I know yall willl fix the IOS12 issues
Unreliable  needs lots of work

Many reviews have already pointed out the unreliability of the importing feature. For me, it sometimes doesn‚Äôt show up unless I go away from the files tab and come back to it. The fact that I keep getting asked if I want to save my document after I‚Äôve exported it makes  the process really slow. So for example, I will open a document, press save, pick a name, file type, and location, hit save, and then try to open another file, and I will get asked if I want to save the current document without closing. That seems unnecessary. I should be able to switch between files either with them auto saving or the app trusting that if I am moving away from the document I‚Äôve finished with it.
The app also seems to be slow to respond to some button press. In previous versions it would also say how many pages out of the total document it‚Äôs converted which was useful to know.
Also, the app is still not integrated with iCloud. This is my main cloud service and I keep having to email myself documents I already have just so I can import them from my email.
Also, more of an iPad feature but it would be great to be able to use the app in landscape mode which is as of now unavailable..
Lastly, smart invert. I am someone who likes to look at the interface of my screen and use voiceover to read the elements. Now, smart invert, that is extremely useful in every other app on my phone, turns the interface to light. I realize the app is already set up for contrast, but I shouldn‚Äôt have to turn off smart invert to use KNFB and turn it on for the rest of my phone. The reader view is slightly different because I can customize the text color and background color, but the rest of the interface is extremely uncomfortable for me to look at. A simple fix would be to double contrast the whole app instead of just the camera so that the theme stays consistently dark with the rest of my apps.
The actual OCR capabilities of the app work well but the user experience is far from perfect. As a student in college that paid the full price of the app, I should have no issues with this app. But for now I am sorry to say it is not worth the price.

I have not been able to get saved files to open and read and then close remaining unchanged.  It seems to modify everything I had saved if I open it to find out what it was.  There seems to be no way to close the file intact as it was without it being "modified" and changed in the date order, so that it is like a needle in the haystack to find again according to date it was first saved.  I don't want to modify what I saved by the simple act of opening it to read it.  It mostly doesn't seem to read a previously saved pdf that had obviously read easily in the past either. The OCR function which used to work rather straightforwardly like as in Kurzweil 1000, now is like a "keepaway" game.  It will only warn you that you can't change whatever it does to your saved image through this next attempt to get the app to recognize an image it once easily recognized.  Even if you don't choose to modify or save or even OCR what you've opened to just peek at with your ears like you could before, it becomes "modified" and it's search order is jumbled up as well as text that wasn't that jumbled before.  I never saved undecipherable files to begin with.  It is changing every file I open rendering it useless.  I used to be able to open it, and quickly find a file and use it on the street or in an appointment or meeting.  There's just no way to get that to happen now.  I've just spent hours here at home trying to sort out a way to use my files again, and it's just not working. I don't have hours to try to hope to retrieve anything on the go anymore.  I remember the first time I got the app maybe two December's ago how amazing and exciting it was to use in real time to read a menu, the first time out.  How I could find the first recipe I saved from a pdf!  I was so amazing.  It wasn't broken.  It didn't need to be fixed.  
It's like a trainwreck now.  It had been expensive but worth it, even with some limitations.  It has been hobbled! Makes me sad.
Version 3.0 is awful! Please fix it! I am a long-time user and I paid full price!

I like everything I‚Äôve learned about the new version. The access to one drive and Dropbox is great. Batch processing is greatly improved‚Äîtelling me how many pictures I have taken. Saving and deleting files is now stable. Having the option to save and view files as PDF is a good addition.

The fact that such an app exists at all to help those of us who can‚Äôt see well enough to read print is worthy of three stars, so I am grateful we have this tool. That said, this behaves more like a free app than one I spent $100 on. First of all, where are the updates??? We are coughing up the money, so you should be providing frequent updates. My biggest issue with the app is trying to line up the shot when scanning a document. The phone vibrates wildly, which I gather is supposed to indicate whether or not it is being held at a level angle over the page, but I find this almost impossible to get just right and more annoying than helpful. Can‚Äôt alignment of the page be done electronically during image processing? Secondly, I wish it behaved like banking apps when you are taking a picture of a check for an electronic deposit. You simply hold the phone over the document and move it around a bit until it is lined up. Once it is aligned, the app automatically takes the picture for you and processing begins. For $100, why isn‚Äôt this app doing the same? The technology obviously exists. Instead, it is a tedious game of guess-and-check where I have to continuously press one of the volume buttons to get a status update on whether or not I am lined up. Even The motion of reaching to press this button makes it harder to steady the phone, so I never feel like I get a really good shot. These announcements should happen automatically. Finally, the documents generated, while often producing some readable text, usually also have a mess of garbled text and random symbols, making it very hard to find what you are looking for. I know the technology exists nowadays for OCR processing to work much more smoothly than this, and again, at the price you are asking, your app needs to be a lot better. If I had it to do over again, I wouldn‚Äôt have purchased this app and would have just settled for something free that basically gets the job done comparably well.  Many blind and visually impaired people are on fixed incomes, so taking a chance on something like this with no option of getting your money back is a big deal.

Since updating to 11.2.5 . I can no longer safe knfb files. This app is in my opinion one of the greatest OCR recognition out there very pricy but worth itüëçüèæ. But at 99.99 there should not be any issues with iOS updates. Again! The save knfb file feature crashes every time I try to save a file using iOS 11.2.5 . Developer PLEASE GIVE US AN UPDATE!!!! and please be on top of future updates because the apple corporation loves them and that process has destroyed developers and clients.
Totally worth the price helps me everyday and can be used so many different ways

This is a great app for single-page scanning! With a couple fixes it could be great for multi-page scanning, too (more about that below).

Bought at $50 (50% off the regular $100 price), its OCR has proven very accurate and quick, amazing me at how it can accommodate automatically for slightly curved pages and such. I appreciate how you can add pages to existing files at any time. Thanks to the developers who continue to refine the app!

While it is over 90% there, it is too rough for a $50 app (let alone $100 at the regular price). Scanning a document over 35-40 pgs consistently causes the app to crash. (I've resorted to scanning longer documents into multiple 35-page files in knfbReader, a rather untidy but functional workaround.) The app also lacks bookmarking, an essential feature for multi-page documents, especially for the visually impaired. I have resorted to exporting the text as a txt file and importing it into the Voice Dream app, which has superior text-to-voice and ereader capabilities than knfbReader (e.g. use a slider to move forward and back through the text, higher quality voices, automatic bookmarking saves where you left off, syncs with Pocket, displays the amount of time it would take to listen to a selection next to the name, etc.)

Note: I've noticed that the device you use to scan can make a significant difference in scan speed. Changing from an iPod touch 5th gen to an iPhone 6 doubled my scan speed, in part due to faster focusing. When possible, scanning two facing pages of a book at a time doubled my scanning speed again. Tip: Use as bright a light as possible to speed up focus time and, therefore, scan time's under lower light conditions focusing can take considerably longer.

A couple other requests include: 
- Cloud syncing between devices without requiring manually exporting from one device and importing into the app on another device
- More polished user interface

I am sighted and use this app to increase the number of articles and books I can go through by listening instead of reading. I tend to listen to more audiobooks than I read paper books, and my hope is to make more paper articles and books readily accessible in audio form. This app is a great example of how improving accessibility for some can improve it for all. 

In short, knfbReader is a diamond in the rough. At this price, I expect better quality. Once the crashing and bookmarking have been worked out, it could be magnificent. (Then, I would give it 5 stars.) The developers are actively working on it, so with continued effort they may yet refine knfbReader into a solid app worthy of the price.

Being blind and having a great item in my arsenal of adaptive technology is not only useful,it is a must. I strongly recommend this for anyone who has a visual disability. It seems a bit expensive but it is well worth the money for a one time purchase and no in app purchases. I did not even mention the convenience and easy to use and very fast translation.

OK, simply put, if your visually impaired in anyway that you were not able to read text normally, I highly recommend this app, in fact, this app is far more superior to my Parul camera that I have on my computer. That being said, there are two issues, either that or huge but would be nice if they got fixed.

1. Batchmode - this mode allows you to take photos of multiple pages before the app processes the images into text to read to you. The problem is that this mode has a tendency to crash randomly, making the user have to routinely save the batch every 15‚Äì20 pages.

2. Photos - for whatever reason, this app holds onto the photos of the pages. This makes sense for legally blind users who want to see any photos that were on the page, but for the 95% of the rest of the time it makes this app a major memory hog if you use it a lot or if you use it to say scan a text book for school. I would really recommend the developers to give the option to delete the photos to help conserve memory on smart phones as well as when it backs up to the cloud.

Side from those two things, yes the price is very steep but it is so worth it if you prefer to just have all of your visually impaired and blind tools on one device rather than walking around like Batman with the utility belt.

I personally love the KNFB app. It has worked remarkably well and has been a real life changing app. The "but" is there because lately it has been more unusable than usable. The KNFB app really started going downhill just before the iOS 9 update and got worse on the iPhone 6s. At that time, we had to wait forever to get an update just to make the KNFB app usable. I say forever, "but" it was really only about a month; "but" for as much as I use the app that felt like forever. The app worked good after the update at first, "but" now the speech rate is all kinds of crazy and it will not save my settings. The most annoying problem though is that the app constantly crashes. If I scan multiple pages the app will get about halfway through the conversion and then crash. Making me start all over again; causing me to waste an enormous amount of time! Now, again, I have been waiting 2 weeks for an update to correct the issues. This is very frustrating because of the amount I use the KNFB app. Also, (this might just be me) "but" I believe if I pay $100 for an app I shouldn't have to work through constant crashes, messed up speed rates, and reset my settings every time I open the app. I understand it takes time to go through the process; so maybe I'm just too inpatient. "But" then I think: wait, it's a $100! We shouldn't have to wait SO long for corrective updates! Once an update is released and the issues solved; I will gladly come back and give the app the five star rating that I personally know it  deserves.

WOW! I have used about every iOS scanner out there and this one beats them all. Hands down. I do a church web page and a lot of the material I put on the site is from the church newsletter. Print form. And so, it needs to be converted to text to be formatted for the website. Being able to send the outcome directly to Pages, I can then go on my desktop and format the text and get it ready for the Web. The batch scan feature along with the tremendously  great accuracy and speed, enhance my work flow. The $99.99 seem like a lot but you get what you pay for and then some. This App  was recommended by my blind friend who runs a vending machine business. Now I SEE why he recommended it to me, his sighted friend.

I bought this app in part because Google Drive was advertised as a backup option, but to my frustration and $99.00 lighter wallet, turns out that wasn‚Äôt‚Äô the case. Highly disappointing. Only offering Dropbox feels so 2012. It is very limiting and available storage is very small when comparing to Google Drive and even OneDrive/OneDrive for Business or iCloud.
There are a couple of buttons where it would seem that a better and more streamlined user experience could be had by converting them to picker items with Voiceover. Mainly in the speech and document language buttons on the scanned document page. Currently, you have to double tap through to get the the next screen where you interact that the picker options anyway. Just feels like an unnecessary step.
I‚Äôd be happy to revise my rating with a future update if some of these issues are improved upon and other cloud storage options are provided than just Dropbox.

I was very excited to try this new app, but am very disappointed. There are a number of problems for a person with low vision:

1)	the icons are not intuitive, and there is no simple legend in the complete manual to show what function each icon performs.
2)	the printed version on the phone is almost, but not quite, large enough for me to read. My vision is approximately 20/100 and the large font on my iPhone allows me to read e-mails and texts easily. Ironically, this app doesn‚Äôt even allow for the same large fonts available in these basic iPhone functions.
3)	The first images I took resulted in a text translation that was imply jibberish. I took a picture of a book page, but the text on the screen, and the read aloud translation made no sense. 

An app like this is sorely needed for people who simply have low vision, but aren‚Äôt completely blind. I sincerely hope that there will be improvements for those of us who can almost function, but not quite, without adaptive technology.

This is, by far, the best OCR app. When I can get it to work, the results are excellent.

Unfortunately, getting it to work is a bit of a challenge. First, the field of view report does not give consistent information. I‚Äôve run the report multiple times in the same position and get different results each time. Additionally, sometimes the field report fails to give voice feedback, and you have to dismiss the app and relaunch.

When performing OCR, you often only get portions of the text; this even occurs when the field report indicates that alignment is perfect. Just as in the field report, OCR often fails to provide voice output.

These flaws are a shame, since the app works well when it *does* work.

I have performed several scans that included different types of materials and conditions. I will tell you that no other app I have used even comes close to producing the results of the knfbReader app. I have used Prizmo, which is the only other app that comes close. Yes, the knfbReader app was designed with the visually impaired or blind person in mind and that despite what some will say is its strength. I do not believe this app costs $99.99 just to overcharge a certain segment of the population, the ‚Äúblind tax,‚Äù but instead is a high-quality app that delivers on the features and performance promised. I could say quite a lot, but it really comes down to one thing and that is for you to decide if you want to work hard or work smart. Yes, you can pay less for apps that will do the job, but these other apps require a lot more fiddling to find the best position for extracting enough legible text to figure out what you got. People have used stands of all types to get the job done. With the knfbReader app you do not really need any stands etc. If you have one it will certainly help and especially when doing batches of image captures using the automatic mode. Otherwise, you can simply hold your device about eight to 10 inches above the material and nearly instantaneously get your results. I have absolutely no regrets paying $99.99 for an app that meets a need and I can remove all other apps. BTW, when I figure the cost of apps and a couple of stands I have purchased in trying to find a good solution I probably spent more than the cost of the knfbReader app. :)
I bought it, used it, and love it.  Talk about a product that is simply amazing.  It's everything it was promised to be.

Fast, accurate, good feedback about what the camera can see, great braille support. Faster multipage scanning than the competition. The elegance of the interface and quality of results may justify the price tag if you have to deal with a lot of print.

I used to love this app, but it seems like ever since the app became free to use the quality has dramatically dropped. When I first got this app, I would hold it up in front of the LCD display screens on the thermostats in our home to set the temperature. Our thermostats were pushbutton to adjust the temperature, and had switches to change the mode or turn the fan on and off. If I knew what‚Äôs the setting was on, I would know how many times to press the button to set it to the desired temperature. For instance, Tap Tap See would tell me that the thermostat was set at 60¬∞, and that the house temperature was 65. I was then able to realize that if I wanted to set the heat at 68 that I would simply need to push the up button eight times. Recently though, I have resorted to calling AIRA when I need help adjusting the thermostat as this app will say something along the lines of thermostat is set at 20/5. Also, I loved the new video feature that was being introduced, with this app, but this feature was very short-lived. I have anxiously been waiting for it to return for nearly a year now, and nothing has come out. Unless a miracle occurs, I suspect this app is finished with updates and will soon be retired just as the Look Tell money reading app was.

This app is great when it comes to acurate discription of objects and seens and such. It's really cool to point it out the window when I'm in a car or something and it tells me pretty accurately what's out there. Like "Brown field with green trees" or "Black car parked in front of store". It also is really good with discribing objects. I was in a dentist office and they had decorations all around of wrapped presents. I tryed to get seeing AI to tell me about the boxes but it kept focusing on other things like the chair or the table. But tap tap see said "Red and white striped box" which is exactly the information I wanted. I usually use Seeing AI for money and stuff because it's quick, but I use this one for objects because Seeing AI not very good. But, one time, I opened the app and it said something like "Tap the right side of the screen for pictures and left side for video". I was interested, and tryed it. But it just took another picture. I tryed it in landscape, but same thing. I even looked it up on the website and it said it could do 10 seconds of video, so I tryed again. Still, just a picture. I tryed doing a video with the Galory and I tryed that. Only pictures showed up. The video thing really got my hopes up but it doesn't work. Maybe something happened because it's not in the app discription. If it wasn't for this, it would be a 5 stars most definitly. But because of this it gets the rating it did. I really think if your going to make something for a visually impaired person, make some better directions or if it's not doing it anymore take those direction of the website. Again, I'm really sorry for this, but I think you shouldn't do that.

This is the first app I show people who are interested in what a blind person can do with an iPhone, and it will be the first I recommend to any new user. It is absolutely a game-changer for us. Need to know the color of your socks? Need to be sure you're posting a picture of your cat to Facebook and not calling your grandma a furry nightmare? Wanna know the license plate number of the car in your driveway? This app does all of that quickly and easily. You do have to pay after the first hundred photos as some kinds of pictures are crowdsourced for answers, but it's entirely worth it. You immediately need far less help day to day and that is priceless.

App can recognize any object, place, part, thing... Just point the camera, take a picture, and it will accurately speak what is in that direction. Have you ever  wanted an app that would just take a picture and describe what the picture is? Have you ever wanted to know what that thing is that was on the store shelf? Well, with this app, it's possible! I can't tell you how many times I wanted to know what kind of candy is on a shelf at a store, but I just haven't been able to figure it out! With this app, you can. I wish there was seriously a 10 star rating, because I would totally give this app a 10 star rating. I mean come on, they make you pay 4 bucks on up  a month? That's less than they should make you pay for it, for all the things that it does!  People want to complain that you need to  pay for the app? It's stupid! I mean, come on! These wonderful people put so much time into this app, if people want to complain just because they have to subscribe to the app, and they have to pay a lousy $4 or up!  That's nothing! I just love this app so much, that I couldn't bear just pay $10, and have to pay $10 again after the end of the month. So, I did the next best thing! I paid for three months. Because, I get so much use out of this app, I felt like paying for three months, and getting Not only  my moneys worth, but my pictures worth, Since they are unlimited pictures!  TapTapSee, you guys are the best, as far as describing pictures, and making the results come fast! I can't give you guys enough gratitude! I was so amazed, that this app can read labels, read mail, and so much more! I think you guys are doing a wonderful job for The blindness  community, and thank you very much for putting out a wonderful app! Rock on!

This is a great app. It can be a great help to many with all levels of visual impairment.  We use it regularly in our disability outreach (moreableinc.org) with great results and consumer feedback. It's too bad because it's hard to find good identifier apps out there. and this  app was really really good.  the blind have to already pay so much for adaptive equipment as it is. This was awesome while it lasted. tap tap see just went bye bye.
I tried this app it was very helpful. I'm not blind I just tried this app out it be great for seeing impaired

This app works as a good identification of objects for blind people. It also is extremely helpful in that we can take recognizable pictures to show our cited friends without having to think up a verbal description which may or may not be accurate. Good show.

Fabulous! Amazing! So easy. It is literally as easy as open, point, click. After it gives you a few pictures to sample it will tell you to pick a payment plan. Seven dollars for 100 pictures or nine dollars unlimited monthly. I chose unlimited monthly. I will be using this every day all day long.

It used to be a great app and it used to work really well but now you have to pay 9.99 for pictures for one month. I if you happen have the old version keep a hold of it and do not update it. t seems like that's a high price. This app is so good that I took a picture of a tv screen and it told me who was playing, that it was basketball, and that the score was 36 to 55 and the winning team.. Wow. I also regularly use it to snap photos of items that I can't identify. I am totally blind. And I can snap photos from inside of a car and it never fails to tell me what we are driving by. For example, it said at one point today "photo of a car in parking lot with green trees and a brown grassy field nearby. " this was taken from a moving car. Another great use of this app is to snap photos of food to make sure it is what you want to open. Snap a photo of each side of a box of food and it will analyze each side of it. Snap photos of people and it tells you what kind of shirt they are using. Amazing.

I am not liking to pay for pictures that I take. $10 a month is outrageous. I don't want to pay for a subscription for this app. If I looks like I will have to find a Nother identifier app that won't charge weird rates like that. did pay $10, it had better be for the app itself. Come on now.

Went around the office to identify a lot of things and even some items that appear on screen, e.g. Image attachment.  I am so impressed with this product, I'll be sure to show it to all the other Voice Over users in my circle.

Thank you so much!

I got this for my blind father. He is still learning to use it but even I have fun trying to stump the app! I don't even know where to begin in praising this app. I can identify canned  goods and frozen food easily now. I no longer have to worry about placing them in an exact position so that I can find them later. It's so simple for me to discover the brand name of the food that I'm buying, which allows me to log everything that I'm eating more accurately. I can identify money. I can take pictures of my cat and share them on Facebook. I can take pictures out my window to try to see what my cat is looking at out there. The possibilities really are limitless when it comes to what you can do with this amazing app. When you take a picture, the results come back quickly, and the descriptions are accurate and detailed. One of my favorite apps of all time.
I love this app, and I think it is 1 of the best apps that are on the Appstore that are actually worth having.  THanks a lot for making this app.

I have never written a review before, but I have a strong urge to enhance this app for my Deafblind community, including myself. I do love the simplicity of its design and its grayish icon of an eye. I strongly suggest that it should have an accessible version for Deafblind (DB)‚Äî they would appreciate reading descriptions and converted text so that they won't feel inhibited in their access to visual information around them. Another suggestion is I don't know what limitations an iPhone 5 has, but it would be incredible to know the sound information around them, such as the "inaudible", "music playing", "chatting" and so on. Siri is able to recognize sounds and therefore, it should have a technology to detect sounds. In addition, it should include three different modes: Braille/Sizable text, Sound, and both that they can switch seamlessly. I will restore my 5 star rating when it's accessible for DB.  :'(

I took pictures of pretty much everything I could find when I first got this app, and it identified everything. When the novelty wore off, I focused only on food. I'm good at identifying some food items by touch but some items are hard to identify on my own. For instance, I might know I'm picking up a TV dinner, but which one? All my soup bottles feel the same as well. I have frozen veggies and meats in my freezer. With this app, I don't have to get my hands cold feeling inside the bag to see what it is I have in my hand. I only need to reach inside the bag now once I'm sure of what the item is. No longer do I need to wonder if I'm actually opening my can of tomato sauce instead of beans. What's great about this app is that you can submit up to five pictures at once. So if you're not sure where the front of the box is vs. the back, you can take pictures of both sides.  Or you can take  a picture of a can from different angles if you're not sure where the name of the item is on the can. This makes the app very effective. I'm very pleased with this app.

For a free app, this one isn't bad. It recognized all that currency bills I presented it, and most of the various products. However, there should be a repeat feature. What if the person did not hear what was read the first time?
Also, under the about heading, there is no apparent text. At least voiceover does not see it. What is the point of having an about heading when there is no text present?
Aside from these things, this app is pretty neat. I hope it continues to be further developed, and it certainly has the potential to be extremely useful for those of us who are visually impaired.

This product was excellent for identifying currency, but I was disappointed that I could not get it to recognize labels on cans of soup. It would only say "canned good". As a totally blind person, I found currency easy to position because I could just lay the currency flat and hold the phone directly above it. But to identify anything else, I think this product might work well for people with some vision, but has a long way to go in terms of being user friendly for totally blind consumers.

I really like this app a lot. My only complaint is that the results are only spoken once, and if you miss it, there's no way to go back and repeat or review. It appears that humans may be processing the pictures.

The first thing I will say concerning the Digit-Eyes app is this; if you are a person easily frustrated and/or unwilling to put  effort into challenges, I strongly recommend you avoid this app.

The above comment is not intended to diss digitize it anyway. It‚Äôs just that it will take some time and practice to get fairly successful with digitize. I personally find it to be an extremely helpful option because I live alone and I got, frankly, tired of accidentally adding sauerkraut to my chili when I think I‚Äôm adding tomatoes. In short, I find digit-eyes an extremely useful and usable app!

I don‚Äôt often write reviews, but this app was so disappointing, I felt compelled to. In 15 minutes of trying to scan multiple items, even with sighted assistance, I was only able to scan one item using the app. And, that item wasn‚Äôt even in the database. Even when the camera was pointed directly at the barcode, the scanner did not pick it up. Please save your money, and buy an overpriced coffee at Starbucks.

I also find it very useful to identify spices‚Ä¶ I pondered for weeks and had to label my spices and realized that they already have a barcode on them and I just scanned them and know what is what‚Ä¶ Totally awesome‚Ä¶ if you have trouble printing labels to years‚Ä¶ Just spend a couple dollars and buy some from Digit-Eyes‚Ä¶ It isn't worth the prostration I am always very hesitant to spend money on apps‚Ä¶ I reluctantly bought this airport $10 and as I say‚Ä¶ It's worth $10,000 to me‚Ä¶ there is a slight learning curve to learn how to find and scan the barcode‚Ä¶ But in a day or two‚Ä¶ I am old pro‚Ä¶ If you have questions‚Ä¶ They are there to answer the telephone‚Ä¶ That is a big plus there is some prostration with learning to find the barcodes‚Ä¶ But be patient‚Ä¶ Work with it‚Ä¶ And‚Ä¶ As I say‚Ä¶ It is worth it's weight in gold‚Ä¶ another thing that is pretty cool about the app is when it recognizes the barcode you hit the more information link and in many instances it gives you nutritional data for that particular product‚Ä¶ also‚Ä¶ Some products will give you cooking instructions also no more six or seven open cans in the fridge that were mistakenly identified last week and never use because I open the sauerkraut when I was looking for the kidney beans‚Ä¶ LOL

Customer some more support is terrible! Been trying a month to get technical support to help with the printer time out problem. Both phone call attempts and email attempts failed to get a response. Do not recommend relying on this apps technical support for any assistance. Less than one star.

I like this app, but except for one thing. I would also like to have the prices read along with the item. How are you suppose to know what the price if you're blind/visually impaired? Doing a web search will take to much time, and you won't be able to find someone all the time in the store. What do you do then???!

This app if you know and have patients how to learn how to focus your camera and look for the barcode is very good. It can be difficult to use but not because of the app, more because of my not knowing where the barcode is.  I appreciate the beeping to let me know that I am close to the barcode.

Once the barcode is found, the app will give you the name of the item. It does not search any product databases to give detailed information. I am not sure why it claims to be the best. I have already found three average products it does not recognize. Also, if you are looking for cooking instructions this app will not suffice.

While their are several barcode scanners available, this one is the simplest to use without sighted assistence. Right away it recognizes a lot of the things in the average kitchen. Figuring out where exactly the barcode is on items to scan them in the first place is the hardest part but does get easier with practice/experience. The more advanced functions of the app are optional, but it only gets more and more useful the more you dive in. Definetly read the website's tips to get all the use out of it.

It helps to turn objects on their side, and scanned from above. It still takes some time for some objects that are larger, but it does work. Certain things are found relatively easily, and it Recognized most of the things that I threw at it. Somethings have directions for use, other things do not. I would say that overall then, this is a quick, or relatively so, way to at least figure out what you're holding.
I've had this app for about 2years now, and it's still useful. Hands down this app has helped me so much and is a great tool for finding products in my kitchen.

Bought this app for my visually impaired mom. When it works, it works great. But most of the time even with a perfect image of bar code, the app can't see it. Seems to like boxes better than cans. Only worked about 10% of the time. Please note I am not complaining about local brand bar codes needing to be added. If that is all it was this would be a great app. But it just doesn't "see" the barcode to begin with. App should been free or at least no more than $3.

This app works with the built-in device voice over.  There are many free QR code scanners and creators that will do the same thing.  Very disappointing I paid for this. I thought it had something more for the price.  Run - don't walk - from this app.

I've been using Digit-Eyes since it first came out.  While it takes a little bit of learning to get good at scanning, once you get the hang of it, it's amazing how useful this app can be.  I use it primarily to identify cans in my pantry.  It's faster than putting labels on incoming stuff.  You get to know where the bar code is, how to old the can, and can have successful scans in a second or three.  The new extended information is great too.  For many things I scan, I can get ingredients and cooking instructions.  The developers are fast, friendly, and really want to help you get the most out of the app.

Once I got the technique for how to place and hold the phone, I got wonderful results with this application. Definitely worth the $. It was frustrating to use at first, but it was my scanning technique that was causing my frustration, and not the application. It works well.

This is a great app. I am totally blind, and I have been using the app all day since I got it last night. it is important, to go to the website read the instructions, follow the instructions and then try using the app. Note, I'm using 3 G.

This app is great for the price! I've only used it to scan UPC codes so far, and this has been very helpful for identifying items like canned goods in my kitchen. Great app, actually does what it says on the box. I find it particularly useful for reading manufacturer's barcodes to identify products that aren't distinctly packaged. Once you get the nack of scanning the barcodes and a feel for where they are generally located on the packaging (see www.digit-eyes), it becomes easier and easier. If you can't see well enough to read, invest some money in this app and some time in learning to use it for worthwhile results.Please note that scanning takes some practise, so when you start off, remember that the app actually works and its just a learning curve.More manufacturerer info when reading barcodes and fixing a bug which causes the app to exit after a second scan would get 5 stars from me.
